Graphical abstract Complexes [Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] (nbd=norborna-2,5-diene, cod=cycloocta-1,5-diene, cot=cyclooctatetraene) were investigated as catalysts of polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes into stereoregular cis-transoid poly(monosubstituted acetylene)s. All complexes (without cocatalyst) are highly active in phenylacetylene (PhA) polymerization in both coordinating (THF) and non-coordinating (CH2Cl2) solvents. [Rh(cot)(acac)] prepared in situ by ligand substitution in [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot is efficient in PhA polymerization even in systems with a high cot content. Selection of solvent and cycloolefin ligand of the catalyst allows the control over poly(phenylacetylene) molecular weight (M w =3×104 to 4×105). [Rh(nbd)(acac)] exhibit (moderate) activity also in polymerization of alkylacetylenes (alkyl= n-butyl, tert-butyl, 4-chlorobutyl, cyclopropyl, yields up to 28%, M w up to 7.3×104) and in copolymerization of alkylacetylenes with arylacetylenes. In situ 1H NMR monitoring of polymerization systems revealed monomer-assisted transformation of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes into precursors of polymerization centres consisting in proton transfer from the monomer to acac ligand of the catalyst under release of acetylacetone. [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] catalysts thus differ from the widely used [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 catalyst which is transformed into active centres precursors only in reaction with cocatalyst or a molecule of coordinating solvent and which is efficient only in presence of a proper cocatalyst and/or coordinating solvent. Keywords Catalysis Conjugated polymers Rhodium complexes Kinetics Polyacetylenes 1 Introduction Substituted acetylenes are versatile building blocks for the preparation of a variety of types of π-conjugated polymers [1–27]. In dependence on the synthetic path, following main types of π-conjugated polymers can be obtained from these monomers: (i) poly(aryleneethynylene)s and poly(arylenebutadiynylene)s [3,7,8,10,15,19,22,23], (ii) polycyclotrimers [3,12,28,29] and (iii) substituted polyacetylenes (polyvinylenes) [1,3,30–34]. Polymers of the last type have been synthesized by the chain-growth polymerization of respective substituted acetylenes catalyzed by transition metal catalysts. Ta-, Nb- and W-halides combined with organotin compounds have been used as catalysts for the polymerization of disubstituted acetylenes [32,33,35,36]. Selected high-valent W- and Mo-based compounds and complexes are known to serve as efficient catalysts of the polymerizations of monosubstituted acetylenes. These catalysts (operating in the metathesis mode) have been under intensive development over the past four decades [35,37]. Catalysts based on compounds of Fe [38], Ni [39], Pd [40–42], V and Ti [43] have been applied for the polymerization of monosubstituted monomers significantly less frequently. An important stimulation enhancing the attractiveness of coordination polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes came unambiguously from the discovery and implementation of polymerization catalysts based on Rh complexes in eighties of the last century [35,44–46]. Since then Rh complexes have been reported many times as efficient catalysts that transformed particularly arylacetylenes, propiolic acid esters and N-propargylalkylamides into high-molecular-weight, highly stereoregular, head-to-tail cis-transoid polyacetylenes [1,35,47]. The insertion mechanism has been generally accepted for the polymerization propagation with Rh catalysts [38,48,49], although the results of a recent theoretical study [50] conceded both insertion and metathesis propagation modes. Several types of Rh catalysts have been mostly applied: (i) cationic complexes such as [Rh+(nbd)(Ph-BPh3)−] and [Rh+(cod)2]BF4 −(nbd=norborna-2,5-diene, cod=cycloocta-1,5-diene) [1,35,47], (ii) complexes of the type [RhX(cyclodiene)(phosphine)] (X=alkynyl, vinyl or F) [51–54] and (iii) stable neutral dinuclear complexes of the general formula [Rh(cyclodiene)X]2 [1,35,47]. Complexes [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 and [Rh(cod)Cl]2 are the most frequently used catalysts of the last group. [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 and [Rh(cod)Cl]2 are efficient (i) with addition of a proper cocatalyst (amine-type bases, ethanol, organometallics such as n-BuLi, Et3Al [55–57], that facilitates the dissociation of the dinuclear complexes into mononuclear particles [45,58–62] or (ii) in a polar or coordinating solvent (THF) that may take the role of the dissociation-promoting agent. Complex [Rh(cod)Cl]2 was also anchored (very probably in the form of mononuclear species) on the mesoporous supports containing basic nitrogen groups [60–63]. Resulting materials were highly active in the heterogeneously proceeding polymerization of arylacetylenes [60–62]. Besides frequently applied [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 and [Rh(cod)Cl]2 also [Rh(cyclodiene)X]2 complexes with other cyclodiene [64] or bridged ligands X [65–67] were tested as catalysts of the polymerization of substituted acetylenes. We demonstrated [Rh(cod)OCH3]2 complex as efficient for the polymerization of rod-like acetylenes such benzylidene-4-ethynylanilines [65–67]. On the other hand, complexes [Rh(cod)OCOR]2 and [Rh(nbd)OCOR]2 (OCOR=carboxylato bridge ligand) exhibited only low activity in PhA polymerization [68]. In the preceding decade, several reports were published on the application of neutral mononuclear complexes [Rh(nbd)(acac)] and [Rh(cod)(acac)] (acac=acetylacetonato) in PhA polymerization [69,70]. Usually, the results of “one point” polymerization experiments were reported only. Nevertheless, Mastrorilli et al. showed that the activity of these complexes was not conditioned by addition of cocatalysts (contrary to [Rh(cyclodiene)Cl]2 complexes) [70]. Further Mastrorilli et al. [71] and Hori et al. [72] reported the high polymerization activity of [Rh(nbd)(acac)] and [Rh(cod)(acac)] in the non-standard media such as ionic liquids and supercritical CO2, respectively [71,72]. Several years ago, we reported successful polymerization of 3-ethynylthiophene with [Rh(nbd)(acac)] and [Rh(cod)(acac)] in CH2Cl2 [73] and quite recently we applied these catalysts in the same solvent for the polymerization of nonvicinal diethynylarenes into microporous hypercrosslinked polyacetylenes [74]. With the aim to obtain a more comprehensive survey of the polymerization activity of these mononuclear complexes we performed the systematic polymerization study the results of which are reported in this paper. In this study, the complexes [Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] (cot=cyclooctatetraene) were investigated as catalysts of homopolymerization and copolymerization of aryl- and alkylacetylenes in various solvents. The in situ 1H NMR monitoring of the polymerization systems revealed the monomer-assisted transformation of the above given Rh complexes into the polymerization active centres that helped to explain the established relations between (i) the reaction conditions and (ii) the time course of reactions and the yields and molecular-weight characteristics of polymers formed with these complexes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Phenylacetylene (PhA), (4-biphenylyl)acetylene (4-ethynylbiphenyl) (BPhA), (2-fluorophenyl)acetylene (2FPhA), (2-trifluoromethylphenyl)acetylene (2CF3PhA), n-butylacetylene (hex-1-yne) (nBuA), tert-butylacetylene (3,3-dimethylbut-1-yne) (tBuA), 4-chlorobutylacetylene (6-chlorohex-1-yne) (ClBuA), cyclopropylacetylene (cPrA), acetylacetonato(cycloocta-1,5-diene)rhodium(I) [Rh(cod)(acac)], acetylacetonato(norborna-2,5-diene)rhodium(I) [Rh(nbd)(acac)], acetylacetonatobis(ethylene)rhodium(I) [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)], acetylacetone (Hacac), methanol, (all by Sigma–Aldrich) were used as obtained. CDCl3, CD2Cl2, tetrahydrofuran-d 8 (THF-d 8) (all by Chemotrade) were used as obtained. Cyclooctatetraene (cot) (Sigma–Aldrich) was freshly distilled in vacuo prior to use. Dichloromethane (Lachema, Czech Republic) was distilled from P2O5. Acetylacetonato(cyclooctatetraene)rhodium(I) [Rh(cot)(acac)] was prepared by a simple ligand substitution in [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot under argon. [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)], 200mg (0.77mmol), was dissolved in 5ml of CH2Cl2. Solution of 96μl (0.85mmol) of cot in 2ml of CH2Cl2 was added drop-wise to the starting complex solution (within 20min). Mixture was left to react overnight at room temperature, then the solvent and non-reacted cot were removed in the stream of dry argon at room temperature. Resulting yellow solid was crystallized from CH2Cl2/hexane solution. Yield 212mg (82%). Anal. Calc. for C13H15O2Rh: C, 51.00, H, 4.94 found C, 50.90, H 4.97 (%), 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, δ (ppm)): 5.87 bs (4H, CHnon-coord (cot)), 5.37s (CH, acac), 4.20 d (4H, CHcoord (cot), J =2Hz), 1.96s (6H, CH3 – acac). 1H NMR data was in agreement with literature [75]. 2.2 1H NMR signals of Rh(I)(acac) complexes in THF-d 8 and CD2Cl2 Following survey summarizes 1H NMR signals of [Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] complexes in THF-d 8 and CD2Cl2 (complexes were applied as polymerization catalysts in these solvents, vide infra). [Rh(cot)(acac)] (400MHz, CD2Cl2, δ (ppm)): 5.85 bs (4H, CHnon-coord (cot)), 5.38s (1H, CHacac), 4.07 d (4H, CHcoord (cot), J =1.9Hz), 1.96s (6H, CH3 (acac)). 2.3 Techniques Size Exclusion Chromatography (SEC) analyses were performed on an Agilent Technologies 1100 Series apparatus fitted with an UV–vis Diode Array Detector (DAD). Chromatograms recorded at wavelength of 254nm were used for the determination of molecular weight averages. A series of three PL-gel columns (Mixed B, Mixed C and Mixed E, Polymer Laboratories, UK) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) (flow rate 0.7ml/min) were used. For columns calibration a set of polystyrene (PS) standards (Polymer Laboratories, UK) was used. Following apparent (relative to PS) molecular-weight characteristics are reported: number-average molecular weight, M n, weight-average molecular weight, M w and molecular weight corresponding to the apex of SEC peak, M p. Application of a DAD detector allowed to monitor UV–vis spectra of the polymer eluted from the columns [76,77]. We report UV–vis spectra that correspond to the apex of a given polymer SEC peak in this paper. 1H NMR and 13C NMR measurements were performed using a Varian Unity Inova 400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts of signals in 1H NMR spectra were referenced to the solvent peaks (δ =3.58ppm for THF-d 8, δ =5.32ppm for CD2Cl2 and δ =7.25ppm for CDCl3). Chemical shifts of signals in 13C NMR spectra were referenced to the solvent peaks (δ =67.57ppm for THF-d 8, δ =54.00ppm for CD2Cl2 and δ =77.00ppm for CDCl3). Solid-state NMR spectra of polymers were measured using a Bruker Avance 500 WB/US NMR spectrometer in 4-mm double-resonance probehead at carrier frequencies 500.18 and 125.78MHz for 1H and 13C nuclei, respectively. Standard cross-polarization experiments were used to record 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra at MAS frequency of 11kHz. The intensities of excitation and spin-locking fields B 1(13C) expressed in frequency units ω 1/2π were 64kHz and the duration of cross-polarization contact time pulse was 3ms. The intensity of B 1(1H) field of TPPM (two-pulse phase-modulated) decoupling was ω 1/2π =89.3kHz. The repetition delay was 2s. The 13C scale was calibrated with glycine as external standard (176.03ppm–low-field carbonyl signal). The GC–MS analyzes were performed using a GCMS-QP2010 Plus instrument (Shimadzu, Japan), equipped with a 20m×0.18mm i.d., 1μm film thickness Rxi-624SiL MS column (Restek, USA). 2.4 Polymerization experiments Polymerizations were carried out in glass screw thread vials equipped with a magnetic stirrer at room temperature. Reactions were started by mixing solution of catalyst ([Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] or [Rh(cot)(acac)]) in respective solvent (THF, CH2Cl2, THF-d 8, CD2Cl2) with solution of monomer(s) in the same solvent. Polymerizations in bulk were started by addition of monomer to the solid catalyst. Polymerizations were quenched by pouring the reaction mixture into methanol (tenfold volume excess). Precipitated polymers were isolated by the sedimentation in centrifuge or by filtration, several times washed with methanol or mixture methanol/THF (1/1, v/v) and dried to constant weight in vacuo at room temperature. The final polymer yields were determined gravimetrically. Time course of selected polymerizations of arylacetylenes was monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy: at given times 0.6ml of reaction mixture was transferred into NMR cuvette and submitted for 1H NMR analysis (acquisition time 256 transients). Data resulting from 1H NMR monitoring of arylacetylenes polymerizations were used for determination of the polymer yield, Y(P), vs. reaction time dependencies. Values of Y(P) were obtained using Eq. (1): (1) Y ( P ) ( in % ) = 100 A p ( A M + A P ) where A M and A P are integral intensities of all 1H NMR signals of monomer and polymer, respectively. The applied method gave values of the final yields (based on the 1H NMR analysis performed just before the termination) that were in good accordance with the final yields obtained gravimetrically (±5%). Moreover, all polymerizations were monitored by SEC technique: for this purpose the samples of volume from 5 to 20μl were withdrawn from the reaction mixture at given times. Withdrawn samples were diluted with THF and injected into SEC columns. SEC monitoring provided the reaction time dependencies of molecular-weight characteristics of the polymers formed. Moreover, the (absolute) area below SEC polymer peaks was used for determination of Y(P) values at various reaction times for polymerizations which were not monitored by 1H NMR. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Polymerization of phenylacetylene with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] Three mononuclear Rh-acac complexes of a general formula [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] differing in the cycloolefin-type ligand, [Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] were applied as catalysts in polymerization of PhA in THF-d 8 and CD2Cl2 solvents (see Scheme 1 , R=Ph; for reaction conditions see Table 1 ). Reactions were monitored by SEC and 1H NMR techniques. In all cases, the slightly yellow solution of catalyst turned orange after the addition of PhA that indicated PhA transformation to poly(phenylacetylene), PPhA. Later (5–10min), the color of reaction systems changed into red with increasing PPhA yield. The SEC monitoring showed that besides PPhA (M w =3×104 to 4×105) also a small amount of PhA oligomers (1–2% by SEC) with molecular weight about 300 was formed in all studied polymerization systems. 1H NMR spectra of all reaction mixtures recorded 10min after mixing components of the reaction systems contained (i) characteristic signals of PhA monomer (in ppm: 7.45–7.43m (2H); 7.32–7.28m (3H); 3.50s (1H, CH), in THF-d 8, 7.53–7.50m (2H); 7.39–7.33m (3H); 3.15s (1H, CH), in CD2Cl2), (ii) signals of a supplied Rh-acac complex (see Section 2), (iii) signals of formed PPhA (in ppm: 6.95 bs (3H); 6.70 bs (2H); 5.91s (1H, cis-form), in THF-d 8, 7.00m (3H); 6.72–6.69m (2H); 5.88s (1H, cis-form), in CD2Cl2) and (iv) new typical signals of free acetylacetone (Hacac): in ppm 14.91 (in THF-d 8), 15.58 (in CD2Cl2) (s, 1H, OH), 5.33 (in THF-d 8), 5.52 (in CD2Cl2) (s, 1H, CH enol-form), 3.58 (in THF-d 8), 3.56 (in CD2Cl2) (s, 2H, CH2 keto-form), 2.11 (in THF-d 8), 2.20 (in CD2Cl2) (s, 6H, CH3 keto-form), 1.97 (in THF-d 8), 2.03 (in CD2Cl2) (s, 6H, CH3 enol-form). With increasing reaction time, the intensity of signals of PPhA and Hacac was increasing, the intensity of signals of PhA and acac ligand of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes was decreasing. It is to be mentioned that no free Hacac has been detected during blank experiments, in which CD2Cl2 and THF-d 8 solutions of Rh-acac complexes without added PhA were monitored by 1H NMR for 24h after preparation. Examples of 1H NMR spectra of polymerization systems PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)]/CD2Cl2 (reaction time=180min) are shown in Fig. 1 . The highest amount of free Hacac was detected in PhA/[Rh(cod)(acac)]/CD2Cl2 system (vide infra). To bring an additional proof of the Hacac formation we studied this system in vacuo using all-glass apparatus and carefully dried PhA and CH2Cl2. After 180min of the reaction, all liquids were distilled off at room temperature into a side ampoule cooled by liquid nitrogen. The ampoule was subsequently sealed off. GCMS analysis unambiguously confirmed Hacac in the distilled liquid in the amount that roughly corresponds to the Hacac amount determined by 1H NMR for the reaction system of the same composition. On the other hand, no Hacac was detected by GCMS if the same experiment was performed without PhA addition. Evidently, the Hacac formation was conditioned by the presence of PhA in the reaction system. The initial step of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] with PhA reaction thus most probably proceeds as a proton transfer from PhA to acac ligand under the release of Hacac. This process probably gives rise to intermediate (cycloolefin)RhCCPh (Scheme 2 ). The Rh complexes with σ-coordinated CCPh ligand are discussed in the literature as possible precursors of polymerization active centres in Rh-catalyzed polymerizations of monosubstituted acetylenes [50]. 3.2 Influence of reaction conditions on PhA polymerization with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] The quantification of 1H NMR spectra recorded in the course of reactions in PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] systems provided (i) PPhA yield, Y(P), and (ii) fractions of acac ligand transformed into free Hacac, f Hacac, for various reaction times, t r. Parameter f Hacac was defined as follows: (2) f Hacac = [ Hacac ] [ [ Rh ( cycloolefin ) ( acac ) ] 0 ] where [Hacac] stands for the concentration of free Hacac at a given t r, [[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)]]0 stands for the initial catalyst concentration. The values of f Hacac were calculated as follows: (3) f Hacac = A Hacac ( A Hacac + A acac ) where A Hacac represents the sum of the CH3 signal areas of free Hacac (the keto- and enol-forms together) while A acac stands for the signal area of CH3 groups of acac ligand in a [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complex. The data resulting from the monitoring of PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] reaction systems are given in Table 1. Y(P) vs. t r dependencies are shown in Fig. 2 (for the polymerizations in THF-d 8) and in Fig. 3 (for the polymerizations in CD2Cl2). Fig. 4 shows f Hacac vs. t r curves for the polymerizations in CD2Cl2. Summarized data show that all three [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes are efficient catalysts of PhA polymerization in both tested solvents providing (PPhA) in the yield ranging from 86 to 100%. The type of polymerization solvent was found to affect particularly the initial stage of polymerization. A comparison of the conversion curves given in Fig. 2 with those given in Fig. 3 clearly shows that a higher initial polymerization rate was achieved in CD2Cl2 than in THF-d 8 with each of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complex. In both solvents, the polymer yield obtained with [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] complexes was slightly lower compared to the yield resulted with [Rh(nbd)(acac)] complex. This is particularly evident from a comparison of Y(P) values achieved at the initial stage of polymerization (t r =10min, see Table 1). The extent of the catalyst transformation into active centres precursors (Scheme 2) was found to depend significantly on the solvent applied (see Table 1). Values of f Hacac found for the PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] reaction systems in CD2Cl2 ranged from 0.13 to 0.53 (t r =180min, see Table 1) and increased in the following catalysts order [Rh(nbd)(acac)]<[Rh(cot)(acac)]<[Rh(cod)(acac)] (see Fig. 4). On the contrary, values of f Hacac ∼0.05, only, (t r =180min) resulted for all PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] reaction systems in THF-d 8. The higher extent of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] transformation in CD2Cl2 (compare to THF-d 8 solvent) correlates well with the above discussed finding that the initial rate of polymerization was higher in CD2Cl2 than in THF-d 8 (see Figs. 2 and 3). This may indicate that the type of solvent influenced mainly the initiation stage of polymerization (formation of active species from the catalyst) while the propagation in a given PhA/[Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] system was mainly influenced by the amount of active species in the reaction system (the initial monomer concentration was kept constant). Analysis of the molecular weight data summarized for PPhAs formed under various conditions in Table 1 revealed a complex influence of both (i) the cycloolefin ligand of the catalyst and (ii) the polymerization solvent (initial PhA to catalyst molar ratio was constant for all the polymerizations). In both CD2Cl2 and THF-d 8 solvents the M w values of PPhA decreased in the following catalyst order [Rh(nbd)(acac)]>[Rh(cot)(acac)]>[Rh(cod)(acac)]. Roughly the same conclusion can be drawn for the M n values given in Table 1, although the differences between the M n values achieved under various conditions were less pronounced. The influence of polymerization solvent on the PPhA molecular weight varied with the applied polymerization catalyst. Higher M w and M n values were achieved in THF-d 8 than in CD2Cl2 in polymerizations induced with [Rh(cot)(acac)] and [Rh(cod)(acac)] complexes. However, in polymerizations induced with [Rh(nbd)(acac)], just opposite trend was found for M w averages: slightly higher M w values resulted in CD2Cl2 than in THF-d 8 (M n values were mostly unaffected by polymerization solvent). To evaluate a possible influence of eventual transfer reactions on the above discussed molecular weight data we calculated a lower estimate of the theoretical number-average molecular weight, (M n)theor, for each polymerization (see Table 1). Eq. (4) was used for this purpose in which M U is the relative molecular weight of the monomeric unit (M U =102.14 in the case of PhA), r M/C is the initial monomer to catalyst molar ratio (r M/C =100 for all polymerizations discussed in this subchapter). Applied f Hacac (representing the efficiency of the first step of initiation shown in Scheme 2) can be considered as an upper estimate of the overall initiation efficiency (i.e., f Hacac ≥ initiation efficiency). Consequently, (M n)theor values obtained according to Eq. (4) represent a lower estimate of the theoretical number-average molecular weight. (4) ( M n ) theor = M U Y ( P ) r M/C 100 f Hacac A comparison of (M n)theor and experimentally determined M n values (see (M n)theor/(M n) ratios in Table 1) may indicate a higher extent of transfer reactions for polymerization systems with [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] complexes compared to systems based on [Rh(nbd)(acac)] complex. This may explain the lower PPhA molecular weights achieved with [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] compared to those resulting with [Rh(nbd)(acac)]. The initiation efficiency is to be considered as another parameter affecting the PPhA molecular weight. Assuming that the initiation efficiency is proportional to f Hacac one can deduce that the higher values of molecular weight achieved with [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] in THF-d 8 (compare to CD2Cl2) reflect particularly the low initiation efficiency in THF-d 8. Concluding, it should be emphasized that complexes [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] provided similar (high) PPhA yields in both coordinating THF-d 8 and non-coordinating CD2Cl2. In this aspect [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes differ from the complexes of the formula [Rh(cycloolefin)Cl]2 that are reported to polymerize PhA efficiently only in polar or coordinating solvents [62,64]. This finding seems to reflect the difference in the catalysts transformation into the active centres: (i) [Rh(cycloolefin)Cl]2 complexes require a molecule of the polar/coordinating solvent (or additive) to be efficiently dissociated into mononuclear [Rh(cycloolefin)Cl(solvent)] intermediate that subsequently react with a molecule of PhA [45,46,51,57,78]. (ii) The modification of Rh coordination sphere of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes is most probably assisted only by the PhA molecule as discussed above and shown in Scheme 2. Nevertheless, the polymerization solvent together with the cycloolefin ligand were found to influence significantly the molecular weight of PPhA prepared with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)]: our study showed that the selection of these two parameters afforded to control PPhA molecular weight over one order of magnitude (M n from 1×104 to 1×105, M w from 3×104 to 4×105). 3.3 Polymerization of PhA with [Rh(cot)(acac)] formed in situ While [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(nbd)(acac)] complexes used in this study are commercially available the third applied complex, [Rh(cot)(acac)], was synthesized by ligand substitution in commercial [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot. The ligand substitution was smooth [79], nevertheless it was performed with a slight excess of cot. The non-reacted cot was removed by evaporation and crude [Rh(cot)(acac)] was purified by crystallization before its use as a catalyst for the experiments listed in Table 1 (see Section 2). In connection to the polymerizations of PhA with purified [Rh(cot)(acac)] we also studied PhA polymerization catalyzed by [Rh(cot)(acac)] complex formed in situ from [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] via reaction with cot. Results are given in Table 2 . It should be noted that [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] (dissolved in THF, CH2Cl2, benzene) did not show any activity in PhA polymerization under the condition stated in Table 2. To activate [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)], we dissolved the complex in neat cot and allowed it to react with cot for 30min at room temperature prior to the addition of PhA (experiment No. 2 Table 2). The transformation of PhA into PPhA (soluble in reaction system) was immediately started after PhA addition. The yield of methanol-insoluble PPhA was 65% (t r =180min). 1H NMR spectrum of PPhA prepared in this way was in agreement with the spectra of PPhA samples prepared in CD2Cl2 and THF-d 8 (vide infra). Above given results showed the successful transformation of [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] into polymerization-active complex of assumed formula [Rh(cot)(acac)] that polymerized PhA even in neat cyclooctatetraene. Nevertheless, molecular weight of PPhA prepared under these conditions was significantly lower than that achieved with purified [Rh(cot)(acac)] in “standard” polymerization solvents (see Tables 1 and 2). Therefore, in a subsequent experiment (Table 2 No. 3), [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] was dissolved in THF-d 8 and only 10-fold molar excess of cot was added for ligand substitution (30min, room temperature). Also in this case the PhA polymerization proceeded smoothly. The yield of PPhA and its molecular weight obtained under these conditions were very close to those achieved with purified [Rh(cot)(acac)] in THF-d 8 (compare Table 2 No. 3 and Table 1 No. 10). Conditions of experiment No. 3 (Table 2) allowed monitoring the reaction progress by 1H NMR. Representative 1H NMR spectra are shown in Fig. 5 . Spectrum of the parent [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] complex (Fig. 5, part 1) contained two signals due to acac ligand (400MHz, THF-d 8, δ in ppm): 1.92s (6H, CH3) and 5.35s (1H, =CH) and a very broad signal due to the ethylene ligand at 2.82ppm. 1H NMR spectrum of reaction mixtures recorded 10min after cot addition is shown in Fig. 5, part 2. Spectrum contained signals characteristic for cot ligand bidentate-bonded to Rh(I) (400MHz, THF-d 8, δ (ppm)): 4.10 d (4H, CHcoord) and 5.79 bs (4H, CHnon-coord). The former signal corresponded to protons of CHCH groups coordinated to Rh, the latter signal was due to non-coordinated CHCH groups (see [75]). On the other hand, a broad signal of coordinated ethylene (2.82ppm) disappeared from the spectrum. Liberated ethylene evidently remained dissolved in the reaction system and was manifested by a singlet at 5.36ppm [80]. 1H NMR signal (singlet) of non-reacted cot is well evident at 5.71ppm. Intensity of this signal is nine-times higher than the sum of intensities of signals of cot ligand, i.e. one equivalent of cot was consumed in [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] ligand substitution. Results of 1H NMR monitoring confirmed the quantitative exchange of ethylene ligands in [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] for cot ligand under the formation of [Rh(cot)(acac)] complex. We further monitored [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)]/cot/THF-d 8 at prolonged times (up to 300min): obtained 1H NMR spectra did not exhibit any changes from the spectrum recorded 10min after [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot mixing (Fig. 5 part 2) except for the decrease in the intensity of the free ethylene signal (5.36ppm) due to the ethylene evolving from the liquid phase. The results of 1H NMR monitoring thus confirmed the rapid transformation of [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] to [Rh(cot)(acac)] (finished within 10min) and a long time stability of formed [Rh(cot)(acac)]. Spectrum 3 in Fig. 5 was recorded 180min after PhA addition to the system [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)]/cot/THF-d 8. As evident, majority of PhA (signals in ppm: 7.45–7.43m; 7.32–7.28m; 3.50s) was transformed to PPhA (signals in ppm: 6.95 bs; 6.70 bs; 5.91s, PPhA yield=84%) within this time. On the other hand, the intensity of signal of non-reacted cot remained unchanged, i.e. cot was not inbuilt into the formed PPhA. To summarize this subchapter we can state that in situ prepared [Rh(cot)(acac)] catalyst is suitable for the efficient PhA polymerization under optimized conditions. It may be assumed that some other [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes with ligand differing from cod, nbd and cot could be easily prepared in this way from [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] and evaluated (without isolation and purification) for acetylenes polymerization. 3.4 Polymerization of ortho-substituted phenylacetylenes with [Rh(nbd)(acac)] Two ortho-substituted PhAs, (2-fluorophenyl)acetylene (2FPhA) and (2-trifluoromethylphenyl)acetylene (2CF3PhA) were tested in polymerizations catalyzed with [Rh(nbd)(acac)] with the aim to evaluate the influence of ortho-substituent bulkiness on the polymerizability of this type monomers. Complex [Rh(nbd)(acac)] was applied for this study since it was evaluated as the most efficient catalyst in the polymerization of non-substituted PhA (see Table 1). The results are summarized in Table 3 together with the results of polymerization of non-substituted PhA under the same conditions. The polymerizations of 2FPhA provided poly[(2-fluorophenyl)acetylene] (P2FPhA) in the yield of about 90% (t r =180min) that was only slightly less than achieved in PhA polymerization. Molecular weight averages of P2FPhA were higher than those of PPhA. Particularly the values of M n differed significantly being up to 9×104 in the case of PPhA and up to 2.6×105 in the case of P2FPhA. Assuming a similar initiation efficiency for polymerizations of PhA and 2FPhA performed in THF-d 8 (only in THF-d 8 the values of f Hacac were accessible for both monomers, see Table 3) we can ascribe the high molecular weight of P2FPhA to a low extent of transfer reactions in 2FPhA/[Rh(nbd)(acac)]/THF-d 8 polymerization system. Contrary to 2FPhA polymerization, the polymerization of 2CF3PhA with [Rh(nbd)(acac)] was less successful in both solvents: (i) poly[(2-trifluoromethylphenyl)acetylene] (P2CF3PhA) yield of about 20% was attained only despite the prolongation of the reaction time to 24h (ii) molecular weight averages of P2CF3PhA were from one to two orders of magnitude smaller than those achieved for PPhA and P2FPhA (Table 3, Nos. 5–8). On the other hand, values of f Hacac found for 2CF3PhA polymerization systems (f Hacac up to 0.87, see Table 3) were significantly higher than those determined for PhA/[Rh(nbd)(acac)] and 2FPhA/[Rh(nbd)(acac)] systems. The high extent of catalyst transformation under Hacac formation was very probably connected with the fact that 2CF3PhA consumption by propagation was low. The persistently high 2CF3PhA concentration in the systems afforded a continuous progress of the acac ligand exchange reaction depicted in Scheme 2. In the light of this finding one can state (i) that the poor P2CF3PhA yields achieved were not due to suppression of the initial stage of catalyst transformation and (ii) that the bulkiness of CF3 substituent in the vicinity to the monomer triple bond most probably impeded the propagation stage of polymerization. 3.5 Polymerization of alkylacetylenes with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] To evaluate the activity of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes in polymerization of alkylacetylenes (AlkAs) we polymerized n-butylacetylene (nBuA) as a model monomer under the conditions stated in Table 4 . The results (Table 4) show that [Rh(nbd)(acac)] applied in both THF and CH2Cl2 transformed nBuA to poly(n-butylacetylene) (PnBuA) of M w up to 2×104 and M n up to 1.2×104. Nevertheless, the yield of PnBuA did not exceed 18%. An increase in the yield (up to 28%, M w =2.7×104) was noticed in the bulk polymerization (the catalyst was well soluble in nBuA). Contrary to [Rh(nbd)(acac)], the complexes with cod or cot ligands exhibited significantly lower activity in nBuA polymerization. No polymer was formed in THF and CH2Cl2. Some PnBuA was obtained with [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] only in bulk polymerizations (Y(P)<10%, M w up to 6.2×103 and M n up to 2×103). Table 5 compares the results of the polymerization of four different AlkAs: n-butylacetylene (nBuA), tert-butylacetylene (tBuA), (4-chlorobutyl)acetylene (ClBuA) and cyclopropylacetylene (cPrA). The monomers were polymerized either in THF or in bulk under the catalysis of [Rh(nbd)(acac)]. All polymerizations listed in Table 5 provided corresponding methanol-insoluble poly(alkyacetylene)s (PAlkAs): poly(n-butylacetylene) (PnBuA), poly(tert-butylacetylene) (PtBuA), poly[(4-chlorobutyl)acetylene] (PClBuA) and poly(cyclopropylacetylene) (PcPrA). Isolated PAlkAs were soluble in THF and CHCl3. In the case of PtBuA the solubility was deteriorating with the ageing of sample solutions at ambient conditions. Besides the PAlkAs, the methanol-soluble oligomers were formed in yields of about 2–3% (by SEC) in polymerizations of tBuA and ClBuA and 6–8% in polymerization of nBuA and cPrA. 1H NMR analysis indicated that the oligomers consisted of (i) short linear irregular poly(alkyacetylene) chains and (ii) AlkAs cyclotrimers (i.e. 1,3,5- and 1,2,4-trialkylbenzenes). The molecular weight of methanol-insoluble PAlkAs formed as the main products was increasing in the following order of the monomers: ClBuA<cPrA< nBuA< tBuA. While M w =7.4×103 was the highest value attained for PClBuA one order of magnitude higher M w value was achieved in the case of PtBuA (see Table 5). The yield of poly(alkyacetylene)s was increasing in the following order of the monomers: ClBuA∼ tBuA<cPrA< nBuA. Thus, the highest polymerizability was found for nBuA that is the monomer with the linear hydrocarbon alkyl substituent. The replacement of nBu substituent in the monomer by (i) bulky tBu substituent or (ii) heteroatom-containing ClBu substituent caused the decrease of the monomer polymerizability. [Rh(nbd)(acac)] complex applied as polymerization catalyst always showed higher efficiency in the bulk polymerizations (initial monomer concentration 8.1–11.8mol/l) than in the corresponding polymerizations performed in THF (initial monomer concentration 2.4mol/l). The PAlkAs yields of the bulk polymerizations were 1.5–4 times as high as the yields of polymerizations in THF. Numbers of monomeric units incorporated into PAlkA chains per one molecule of submitted catalyst (n MU/n Rh, see Table 5) were from 52 to 102 in the bulk polymerizations and only from 5 to 18 in the polymerizations performed in THF. 1H NMR monitoring of the polymerization systems containing ClBuA, cPrA and nBuA monomers could not provide any information on the initial catalyst transformation because of the overlapping of CH3 signals of acac and Hacac moieties with the aliphatic signals of monomers and polymers. Such a monitoring was possible only in the case of tBuA polymerization. Similarly as in the arylacetylene containing polymerization systems, the transformation of [Rh(nbd)(acac)] under Hacac formation was observed also in the system tBuA/[Rh(nbd)(acac)]/THF-d 8 by 1H NMR (for condition see Table 5). The results obtained by Eqs. (3) and (4) were as follows: f Hacac =0.09, (M n)theor =900 (t r =3h) and f Hacac =0.71, (M n)theor =600 (t r =24h). Evidently, quite high extent of Hacac liberation from the catalyst was achieved. On the other hand, the extent of a subsequent transformation of precursors into the propagating active centres is to be considered as low (i.e. the overall initiation efficiency was much lower than f Hacac values). This can be deduced from the finding that (M n)theor values calculated by Eq. (4) are one to two order of magnitude smaller than the experimentally determined M n values (see discussion to Eq. (4)). Comparison of results in Tables 5 and 1 clearly shows that [Rh(nbd)(acac)] catalyst polymerized AlkAs less readily than it polymerized PhA. On the other hand, no systematic information on AlkAs polymerization with neutral Rh(I) complexes of [Rh(cycloolefin)Cl]2 type are available in the literature and these complexes are considered as inefficient for this reaction [81,82]. Our study showed that [Rh(nbd)(acac)] polymerized AlkAs into corresponding PAlkAs under optimized conditions nevertheless the polymer yields were only up to 30%. The results of 1H NMR monitoring of tBuA/[Rh(nbd)(acac)]/THF-d 8 system showed that tBuA was quite efficient in “opening” the reaction of the catalyst with monomer (liberation of Hacac from the catalyst). Evidently, the low polymerizability of tBuA is to be ascribed to the low reactivity of tBuA in subsequent stages of the reaction (transformation of precursors into active centres and/or propagation). The same conclusion seems to be probable also for other AlkA-containing polymerization systems from Table 5. Mechanistic considerations on polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes with various Rh(I) catalysts indicate that transfer of acetylenic hydrogen from the Rh-coordinated monomer may play an important role in this reaction. Various authors assume the formation of Rh-H species in the course of transformation of catalytic precursors into the active centres [45,46]. Ogawa et al. assumes that the propagation of Rh(I) catalyzed polymerization may be mediated by the transfer of the acetylenic hydrogen from the Rh-coordinated monomer to the preceding monomeric unit of the growing polymer chain [83]. In the light of these considerations, the low polymerizability of AlkA monomers observed in our study may reflect the insufficient acidity of AlkAs acetylenic hydrogen for its efficient transfer in the initiation and/or propagation step of the reaction. 3.6 Copolymerization of alkylacetylenes with arylacetylenes catalyzed by [Rh(nbd)(acac)] Table 6 summarizes the results of copolymerization of nBuA, ClBuA and cPrA with two arylacetylenes (ArA): PhA and (4-biphenylyl)acetylene (BPhA) (more frequent name: 4-ethynylbiphenyl) performed in THF under [Rh(nbd)(acac)] catalysis. The high reactivity of PhA in [Rh(nbd)(acac)] catalyzed homopolymerization has already been discussed. Similar reactivity was found for BPhA: poly[(4-biphenylyl)acetylene] (PBPhA) in the yield of 91% was attained in homopolymerization under the condition given in Table 6. Contrary to PPhA, PBPhA was completely insoluble (THF, CHCl3, benzene). The initial comonomers mole ratio [AlkA]0/[ArA]0 =4 was applied for all the AlkA with ArA copolymerizations owing to the lower reactivity of AlkA compared to ArA (for other conditions see Table 6). Methanol-insoluble copolymers, P(AlkA-co-ArA)s, were analyzed by 1H NMR (vide infra) that provided: (i) the comonomeric composition of the copolymers and (ii) conversion of AlkA and ArA into the corresponding units of copolymers. (see Table 6). All copolymerizations of AlkA with PhA gave soluble copolymers (THF, CHCl3) in the yield from 24 to 28% (with respect to the submitted mass of both comonomers) with the content of AlkA units from 40 to 52mol. %. Molecular weights of copolymers (M w from 27 000 to 61 000) were always higher than molecular weights of corresponding AlkA homopolymers prepared under the same conditions (M w from 3 300 to 20 000) (see Table 5). The conversion of AlkA in copolymerizations with PhA was increasing in the order of monomers: nBuA∼cPrA<ClBuA. Copolymerizations of BPhA with ClBuA and cPrA provided soluble copolymers with AlkA units content of 48mol% and 56mol%, respectively (Table 6 No. 6 and 8). It is worth noticing that the conversion of ClBuA and cPrA in copolymerizations with BPhA was even higher than their conversion in copolymerizations with PhA (Table 6). Described copolymerizations showed a way for incorporation of the units derived from BPhA into soluble polyacetylene chains. It may be assumed that also some other bulky-substituted and/or functionalized ArAs (forming insoluble homopolymers) could be incorporated under the proper conditions into soluble polyacetylenes in copolymerization with AlkAs. Nevertheless, this approach has a limitation as evident from the results of copolymerizations of BPhA with nBuA (Table 6 No. 4): this copolymerization gave an insoluble product probably as a result of insufficient amount of nBuA units in the copolymer. 3.7 Characterization of polymers prepared with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] NMR and UV-vis spectroscopies were applied for the characterization of polymers prepared with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes. 1H NMR spectra of soluble homopolymers (see “Supplementary Material”, Figs. S1 and S2 for representative examples) contained (i) well developed signal in the region from 5.3 to 6.2ppm which is characteristic of vinylic protons in cis-transoid sequences of chains of monosubstituted polyacetylenes [1,81,82,84–86] and (ii) relatively sharp signals due to protons of the pendant groups. In the series of PPhAs prepared with various catalysts in various solvents, no significant influence of these parameters on the character of 1H NMR spectra of polymers was observed. 1H NMR spectra confirmed the high microstructure uniformity with prevailing cis-transoid main-chains configuration for all the homopolymers prepared with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes, i.e. the applied [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes exhibit the same stereospecificity in polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes as complexes [Rh(cycloolefin)X]2 (X=Cl, OCH3) [31,47]. Figs. S3–S7 in “Supplementary Material” show 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra (together with the signals assignment) of copolymers of ArAs with AlkAs prepared with [Rh(nbd)(acac)]. The quantification of 1H NMR aromatic and alifatic signals was utilized for the estimation of the comonomeric composition of the copolymers that is given in Table 6. The broadening of all 1H NMR signals in the spectra of copolymers (in comparison to the signals in the spectra of homopolymers) reflected the random copolymeric character of the analyzed samples. UV–vis spectra of representative polymers prepared with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes (Figs. S8–S14) are discussed in “Supplementary Material”. 4 Conclusions Rhodium mononuclear complexes [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] with nbd, cod and cot ligands were demonstrated as catalysts of chain growth polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes into stereoregular cis-transoid poly(monosubstituted acetylene)s. Catalysts exhibited (i) high activity in arylacetylenes polymerization and (ii) moderate activity in polymerization of alkylacetylenes and copolymerization of alkylacetylenes with arylacetylenes. In the arylacetylenes polymerization, similar yields of polymers were achieved in both coordinating (THF) and non-coordinating (CH2Cl2) solvents. Complex [Rh(cot)(acac)] prepared in situ by ligand exchange of [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot exhibited high polymerization activity even in neat cot. The control over polymer molecular weight (M n from 1×104 to 1×105, M w from 3×104 to 4×105) was attained in the phenylacetylene polymerization with [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] by selection of (i) polymerization solvent and (ii) cycloolefin ligand of the catalyst. The onset of initiation in the [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)]/monomer systems proceeded as the proton transfer from the monomer molecule to the acac ligand under the release of acetylacetone and coordination of CCR ligand to Rh(cycloolefin) moiety. Contrary to the frequently applied [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 catalyst, [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] catalysts did not need either a cocatalyst or a coordination solvent for their activation. coredata.dc:description: Complexes [Rh(nbd)(acac)], [Rh(cod)(acac)] and [Rh(cot)(acac)] (nbd=norborna-2,5-diene, cod=cycloocta-1,5-diene, cot=cyclooctatetraene) were investigated as catalysts of polymerization of monosubstituted acetylenes into stereoregular cis-transoid poly(monosubstituted acetylene)s. All complexes (without cocatalyst) are highly active in phenylacetylene (PhA) polymerization in both coordinating (THF) and non-coordinating (CH2Cl2) solvents. [Rh(cot)(acac)] prepared in situ by ligand substitution in [Rh(ethylene)2(acac)] with cot is efficient in PhA polymerization even in systems with a high cot content. Selection of solvent and cycloolefin ligand of the catalyst allows the control over poly(phenylacetylene) molecular weight (M w =3×104 to 4×105). [Rh(nbd)(acac)] exhibit (moderate) activity also in polymerization of alkylacetylenes (alkyl= n-butyl, tert-butyl, 4-chlorobutyl, cyclopropyl, yields up to 28%, M w up to 7.3×104) and in copolymerization of alkylacetylenes with arylacetylenes. In situ 1H NMR monitoring of polymerization systems revealed monomer-assisted transformation of [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes into precursors of polymerization centres consisting in proton transfer from the monomer to acac ligand of the catalyst under release of acetylacetone. [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] catalysts thus differ from the widely used [Rh(nbd)Cl]2 catalyst which is transformed into active centres precursors only in reaction with cocatalyst or a molecule of coordinating solvent and which is efficient only in presence of a proper cocatalyst and/or coordinating solvent.
coredata.dc:title: [Rh(cycloolefin)(acac)] complexes as catalysts of polymerization of aryl- and alkylacetylenes: Influence of cycloolefin ligand and reaction conditions
